subject: Add functional test for ip filtering with regex
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-03-02 03:22:11.000000000', 'files': ['nova/tests/functional/test_list_servers_ip_filter.py', 'nova/tests/fixtures.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/b6a99a390caf2c143f3211c40f2ac7f5d51c9c1d', 'message': "Add functional test for ip filtering with regex

There was a bug in Tempest where it would filter the
list of servers by fixed IP address and expected to
only get back one server but sometimes got more than
one. That was because the IP of one server was
a prefix of the IP of another server, and because of
the regex used in the _ip_filter method in the compute
API it will return all matches.

This is how the IP filtering has always worked, but
it's not clear we had a solid test coverage of this
scenario so a functional test was written to confirm
the expected behavior and so that we don't regress it
since it's not documented in the api-ref (yet).

Change-Id: If0e6d7ea7ac61a8480bf7f0288b263902536dc59
Related-Bug: #1668828
"}]
commit_message:
Add functional test for ip filtering with regex

There was a bug in Tempest where it would filter the
list of servers by fixed IP address and expected to
only get back one server but sometimes got more than
one. That was because the IP of one server was
a prefix of the IP of another server, and because of
the regex used in the _ip_filter method in the compute
API it will return all matches.

This is how the IP filtering has always worked, but
it's not clear we had a solid test coverage of this
scenario so a functional test was written to confirm
the expected behavior and so that we don't regress it
since it's not documented in the api-ref (yet).

Change-Id: If0e6d7ea7ac61a8480bf7f0288b263902536dc59
Related-Bug: #1668828
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/69/439969/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # The IP on this port must be a prefix of the IP on port_2 to # test listing servers with an ip filter regex. # This port is only used if the fixture is created with multiple_ports=True port_2 = { 'id': '88dae9fa-0dc6-49e3-8c29-3abc41e99ac9', 'network_id': network_1['id'], 'admin_state_up': True, 'status': 'ACTIVE', 'mac_address': '00:0c:29:0d:11:74', 'fixed_ips': [ { 'ip_address': '192.168.1.30', 'subnet_id': subnet_1['id'] } ], 'tenant_id': tenant_id } def __init__(self, test, multiple_ports=False): self.multiple_ports = multiple_ports def stub_show_port(port_id, *args, **kwargs): if port_id == NeutronFixture.port_1['id']: return {'port': NeutronFixture.port_1} if port_id == NeutronFixture.port_2['id']: return {'port': NeutronFixture.port_2} raise exception.PortNotFound(port_id=port_id) mock_neutron_client.show_port.side_effect = stub_show_port def stub_list_ports(*args, **kwargs): ports = {'ports': [NeutronFixture.port_1]} if self.multiple_ports: ports['ports'].append(NeutronFixture.port_2) return ports mock_neutron_client.list_ports.side_effect = stub_list_ports mock_neutron_client.update_port.side_effect = stub_show_port

commit_message:
libvirt: Parse filesystem elements of guest config

LibvirtConfigGuest.parse_dom does not parse filesystem elements, which
decreases area of its usage.

This patch adds parsing of such elements.

Change-Id: I4e19e97ab9ae84d42c151044ede39d1609d98bc2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/66/410666/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_parse_mount(self): xmldoc = """ <filesystem type="mount"> <source dir="/tmp/hello"/> <target dir="/mnt"/> </filesystem> """ obj = config.LibvirtConfigGuestFilesys() obj.parse_str(xmldoc) self.assertEqual('mount', obj.source_type) self.assertEqual('/tmp/hello', obj.source_dir) self.assertEqual('/mnt', obj.target_dir) def test_parse_block(self): xmldoc = """ <filesystem type="block"> <source dev="/dev/sdb"/> <target dir="/mnt"/> </filesystem> """ obj = config.LibvirtConfigGuestFilesys() obj.parse_str(xmldoc) self.assertEqual('block', obj.source_type) self.assertEqual('/dev/sdb', obj.source_dev) self.assertEqual('/mnt', obj.target_dir) def test_parse_file(self): xmldoc = """ <filesystem type="file"> <driver format="qcow2" type="nbd"/> <source file="/data/myimage.qcow2"/> <target dir="/mnt"/> </filesystem> """ obj = config.LibvirtConfigGuestFilesys() obj.parse_str(xmldoc) self.assertEqual('file', obj.source_type) self.assertEqual('qcow2', obj.driver_format) self.assertEqual('nbd', obj.driver_type) self.assertEqual('/data/myimage.qcow2', obj.source_file) self.assertEqual('/mnt', obj.target_dir) <filesystem type="mount"> </filesystem> self.assertEqual(len(obj.devices), 2) self.assertIsInstance(obj.devices[1], config.LibvirtConfigGuestFilesys) self.assertEqual('mount', obj.devices[1].source_type)

commit_message:
libvirt: Parse virt_type attribute of LibvirtConfigGuest from xml

LibvirtConfigGuest.parse_dom does not parse virt_type attribute, which
makes code walking through LibvirtConfigGuest object attributes strange,
suspicious, and not clear, because it analizes virt_type from config
file instead.

This patch adds parsing of this element.

Change-Id: Ie8eea464c6ba63da7292b5458f8a805bcc11ddd3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/47/414747/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
libvirt: Parse os attributes of LibvirtConfigGuest from xml

LibvirtConfigGuest.parse_dom does not parse os attributes (like
os_type), which decreases area of its usage.

This patch adds parsing of such elements (including root attribute
type).

Change-Id: I7619f27dd4d969e795f89daade599734f29345d7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/65/410665/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_ConfigGuest_parse_os(self): xmldoc = """ <domain type="kvm"> <os> <type machine="fake_machine_type">hvm</type> <kernel>/tmp/vmlinuz</kernel> <loader>/usr/lib/xen/boot/hvmloader</loader> <initrd>/tmp/ramdisk</initrd> <cmdline>console=xvc0</cmdline> <root>root=xvda</root> <init>/sbin/init</init> <boot dev="hd"/> <boot dev="cdrom"/> <boot dev="fd"/> <bootmenu enable="yes"/> <smbios mode="sysinfo"/> </os> </domain> """ obj = config.LibvirtConfigGuest() obj.parse_str(xmldoc) self.assertEqual('kvm', obj.virt_type) self.assertEqual('hvm', obj.os_type) self.assertEqual('fake_machine_type', obj.os_mach_type) self.assertEqual('/tmp/vmlinuz', obj.os_kernel) self.assertEqual('/usr/lib/xen/boot/hvmloader', obj.os_loader) self.assertIsNone(obj.os_loader_type) self.assertEqual('/tmp/ramdisk', obj.os_initrd) self.assertEqual('console=xvc0', obj.os_cmdline) self.assertEqual('root=xvda', obj.os_root) self.assertEqual('/sbin/init', obj.os_init_path) self.assertEqual(['hd', 'cdrom', 'fd'], obj.os_boot_dev) self.assertTrue(obj.os_bootmenu) self.assertIsNone(obj.os_smbios) xmldoc = """ <domain> <os> <type>x86_64</type> <loader readonly='yes' type='pflash'>/tmp/OVMF_CODE.fd</loader> </os> </domain> """ obj = config.LibvirtConfigGuest() obj.parse_str(xmldoc) self.assertIsNone(obj.virt_type) self.assertEqual('x86_64', obj.os_type) self.assertIsNone(obj.os_mach_type) self.assertIsNone(obj.os_kernel) self.assertEqual('/tmp/OVMF_CODE.fd', obj.os_loader) self.assertEqual('pflash', obj.os_loader_type) self.assertIsNone(obj.os_initrd) self.assertIsNone(obj.os_cmdline) self.assertIsNone(obj.os_root) self.assertIsNone(obj.os_init_path) self.assertEqual([], obj.os_boot_dev) self.assertFalse(obj.os_bootmenu) self.assertIsNone(obj.os_smbios)

subject: libvirt: Simplify internal usage of get_instance_disk_info
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-28 10:05:21.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/c537f05ee5bd000e6e2466e0047566e11b15fe9c', 'message': 'libvirt: Simplify internal usage of get_instance_disk_info

get_instance_disk_info returns a dict, serialized to a string, but all
internal libvirt callers convert it back to the dict. Considering
existence of _get_instance_disk_info, which returns a dict, but requires
different kinds of parameters, the usage of the method is not
convenient.

This patch does:
- rename _get_instance_disk_info to _get_instance_disk_info_from_xml,
which reflects the method nature;
- declare new _get_instance_disk_info, which returns not serialized
dict;
- make block_device_info parameters of both methods mandatory;
- keep the driver public interface unchanged.

Change-Id: I9c0c6954ba5442414e615225a74df7e42f3d0c98
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-06-28 14:45:18.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/697fd125e1cc900393d5b1d8b3149f42bbe4cea2', 'message': 'libvirt: Simplify internal usage of get_instance_disk_info

get_instance_disk_info returns a dict, serialized to a string, but all
internal libvirt callers convert it back to the dict. Considering
existence of _get_instance_disk_info, which returns a dict, but requires
different kinds of parameters, the usage of the method is not
convenient.

This patch does:
- rename _get_instance_disk_info to _get_instance_disk_info_from_xml,
which reflects the method nature;
- declare new _get_instance_disk_info, which returns not serialized
dict;
- make block_device_info parameters of both methods mandatory;
- keep the driver public interface unchanged.

Change-Id: I9c0c6954ba5442414e615225a74df7e42f3d0c98
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2016-08-11 18:26:15.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/dab2e1fe1fe7ee51a09c145bd756f6aca693da50', 'message': 'libvirt: Simplify internal usage of get_instance_disk_info

commit_message:
libvirt: Simplify internal usage of get_instance_disk_info

get_instance_disk_info returns a dict, serialized to a string, but all
internal libvirt callers convert it back to the dict. Considering
existence of _get_instance_disk_info, which returns a dict, but requires
different kinds of parameters, the usage of the method is not
convenient.

This patch does:
- rename _get_instance_disk_info to _get_instance_disk_info_from_xml,
which reflects the method nature;
- declare new _get_instance_disk_info, which returns not serialized
dict;
- make block_device_info parameters of both methods mandatory;
- keep the driver public interface unchanged.

Change-Id: I9c0c6954ba5442414e615225a74df7e42f3d0c98

commit_message:
Remove signing_dir option

PKI token support has been deprecated in the Ocata release and will be
removed in the Pike release, so we can remove releated parameters.

Change-Id: If8f4cf3db3f315742554be363ae4ab8e70b789ce
Closes-Bug: #1653049

commit_message:
Remove hardcoded signing_dir in keystone_authtoken

None of the other roles have a hardcoded signing_dir and having
it hardcoded points it towards a non-writeable path.

The PKI token format is on it's way out so the signing_dir is
becoming useless (it's only used in PKI deployments).

Change-Id: Ib06fc2b1a8f42b20be03d2578c54d591e82e84d6
Closes-Bug: #1676211

commit_message:
Add a check for legacy hiera element data

The new heat 'hiera' hook is incompatible with the old
tripleo-puppet-elements hiera element. The two formats
should not coexist as they will overwrite each others
config files (last hook to run would win).

To make the end user experience nice we add an explicit check
here. Note: this would require us to clean out old
apply-config data from a prior run during an upgrade to make
sure the check doesn't mistakenly prevent a new deployment
from failing.

Change-Id: I326a2816b6c47b2ba00c33a42ce6e452c5a74dce
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat-agents refs/changes/41/426241/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import subprocessHIERA_ELEMENT_CHECK_CMD = os.environ.get('HEAT_HIERA_ELEMENT_CHECK_CMD', 'os-apply-config ' '--key hiera.datafiles ' '--type raw --key-default ""') def exit_legacy_hiera_detected(): try: subproc = subprocess.Popen(HIERA_ELEMENT_CHECK_CMD.split(" "), stdout=subprocess.PIPE, stderr=subprocess.PIPE) stdout, stderr = subproc.communicate() if stdout: err_msg = ('Legacy hieradata from os-apply-config has been ' 'detected. Please update all of your interfaces ' 'to use the new heat-agents hiera hook before ' 'proceeding') response = { 'deploy_stdout': '', 'deploy_stderr': err_msg, 'deploy_status_code': 1, } json.dump(response, sys.stdout) sys.exit(0) except OSError: # os-apply-config is not installed? Assume there is no legacy data. pass exit_legacy_hiera_detected()

commit_message:
Add pipefail to each command that piped with timestamp

When pipe is added to command, it should still exit with its
result code, so save it by setting pipeline option before each
command.

Close-Bug: #1676156
Change-Id: Ibbe49b4a15a5b7825447a563fe35af85fd48b3ff
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-quickstart-extras refs/changes/23/450023/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: set -o pipefail &&

commit_message:
Rename 'uploads' key to 'container_images'

This will allow this file to be used for both uploading and image
building. The old 'uploads' key will continue to work.

Change-Id: Ie09d784119e53b90e5ad0c9028459486cff177c7

commit_message:
Remove py34 tox env and pypi classifier

Currently only py27 and py35 (not py34) is tested in the gate, so
py34 should no longer be part of the tox environment or part of the
PyPi classifier.

Change-Id: I81058c5df47c4dae3c331d0030141896b6a9f1bb

commit_message:
Pick dynamically the first node for stack validation

When replacing the controller node with resource id 0,
AllNodesValidation will fail because there is an hardcoded reference
to resource.0. With this commit the id for validation is extracted
dynamically with yaql query, picking the first available.
Thanks to Steven Hardy for pointing to the right direction.

Change-Id: I8f2bfacbc005d948bd31ebd51c3d3df3182d5a3c

subject: Replace six.iteritems() with .items()
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-03-25 11:37:41.000000000', 'files': ['congress/datalog/compile.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/congress/commit/9308bd29e730e6fa608ebe046c3014e3e8369e63', 'message': 'Replace six.iteritems() with .items()

1.As mentioned in [1], we should avoid using
six.iteritems to achieve iterators. We can
use dict.items instead, as it will return
iterators in PY3 as well. And dict.items/keys
will more readable. 2.In py2, the performance
about list should be negligible, see the link [2].
[1] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Python3
[2] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-June/066391.html

Change-Id: I333e61b4ff7129186334d716c75b3e286e3522d6
'}]
commit_message:
Replace six.iteritems() with .items()

1.As mentioned in [1], we should avoid using
six.iteritems to achieve iterators. We can
use dict.items instead, as it will return
iterators in PY3 as well. And dict.items/keys
will more readable. 2.In py2, the performance
about list should be negligible, see the link [2].
[1] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Python3
[2] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-June/066391.html

Change-Id: I333e61b4ff7129186334d716c75b3e286e3522d6

commit_message:
Fix some reST field lists in docstrings

Probably the most common format for documenting arguments is reST field
lists [1]. This change updates some docstrings to comply with the field
lists syntax.

[1] http://sphinx-doc.org/domains.html#info-field-lists

Change-Id: I278768c4860ad37d2032e962e76aa8250ff0bbfb

commit_message:
Replace uuid.uuid4() with uuidutils.generate_uuid()

Openstack common has a wrapper for generating uuids.
We should use that function to generate uuids for consistency.

Change-Id: I59e317f8ae1a7ec7cd51f634a59b050df2fb7a44

commit_message:
Remove log translations

Log messages are no longer being translated. This
removes all use of the _LE, _LI, and _LW translation markers to simplify
logging and to avoid confusion with new contributions.

See:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-i18n/2016-November/002574.html
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-March/113365.html

Change-Id: I9474117444e0f16cee32ddce97a82cbf7c3e8f37
Closes-Bug: 1674577

added_lines: ================== Resource Providers ================== Resource providers are entities which provide consumable inventory of one or more classes of resource (such as disk or memory). They can be listed (with filters), created, updated and deleted. List Resource Providers ======================= .. rest_method:: GET /resource_providers List an optionally filtered collection of resource providers. Normal Response Codes: 200 Request ------- Several query parameters are available to filter the returned list of resource providers. If multiple different parameters are provided, the results of all filters are merged with a boolean `AND`. .. rest_parameters:: parameters.yaml - resources: resources_query - member_of: member_of - uuid: resource_provider_uuid_query - name: resource_provider_name_query Response -------- .. rest_parameters:: parameters.yaml - resource_providers: resource_providers - generation: resource_provider_generation - uuid: resource_provider_uuid - links: resource_provider_links - name: resource_provider_name Response Example ---------------- .. literalinclude:: get-resource_providers.json :language: javascript

commit_message:
Use Sphinx 1.5 warning-is-error

With pbr 2.0 and Sphinx 1.5, the setting for treat sphinx warnings as
errors is setting warning-is-error in build_sphinx section. Migrate
the setting from the old warnerrors one.

Change-Id: I8887825011e91701638d207021f875ec74061ba8

commit_message:
Document Pike cycle artifact signing key

Since the Ocata cycle releases are behind us, document that the
pending key for the Pike cycle is now in place as of 2017-03-24 and
the Ocata key is retired from use beyond that date.

Change-Id: Ief302e29769da1de8c6bc18afc1ac1b38fd17d19

commit_message:
Draft statement on PaaS applications

This is a draft TC resolution to highlight the difference between the
requirements placed on OpenStack Infrastructure Services by cloud
native applications and Platform (PaaS) applications.

This draft is motivated by a ML discussion, and a proposal [1] from
Zane Bitter that I believe tries to achieve the same end.

My objective in proposing this draft is to address the same issue in a
slightly different way, and to add an explicit call to action to the
teams that work on the OpenStack Infrastructure Services, and the
teams that work on the OpenStack Platform applications.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/447031/1

Related: I99be9bffe4c269037634cf1883f604a233b9672d
Change-Id: I822bc2fa9b63e670fab047940c41a70d09f4fa9f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/governance refs/changes/08/447708/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ==================================== 2017-03-20 Platform Applications ==================================== The OpenStack mission --------------------- OpenStack's mission is: To produce a ubiquitous Open Source Cloud Computing platform that is easy to use, simple to implement, interoperable between deployments, works well at all scales, and meets the needs of users and operators of both public and private clouds. The special needs of platform (PaaS) applications ------------------------------------------------- OpenStack aims to acheive its mission by providing an open source implementation of an openly designed and implemented API which allows users to provision and manage a variety of compute, storage and networking resource. We refer to these core services as the OpenStac Infrastructure Services. We recognize that there are at least two broad groups of applications that are built on OpenStack Infrastructure Services. One class of applications in the OpenStack cloud are cloud native applications. Users can deploy OpenStack and develop cloud native applications that make use of these API's without the fear of vendor lock-in. Another class of applications on the OpenStack cloud are PaaS applications that building on the core compute, storage and networking components, and provide higher level services which in turn expose open API's. Several OpenStack projects themselves are PaaS applications; Designate, Manila, Octavia, Sahara, Trove, and Sahara are some examples of these projects. Cloud native applications and PaaS applications have different requirements of the underlying compute, storage and networking components. For example, many PaaS applications wish to expose API's that accept KeyStone tokens and perform actions for client applications that result in the provisioning of compute, storage and networking resources on behalf of the end user. The PaaS applications would like to provision these resources from within the requesting users quotas, and in such a way that these resources can interact with other resources directly provisioned by the user. Trove would like to provision compute instances in the user's quota and be able to attach it to networks that are created by the user. Yet, the PaaS application want to shield the resources that they have provisioned from direct actions by the user. In the future, we anticipate that additional PaaS applications may have additional kinds of demands of the underlying OpenStack Infrastructure Services, and these are demands that may not be of any relevance or importance to cloud native applications which directly build on the Infrastructure Services. In recognition of these differences, the Technical Committee hereby directs all projects to recognize the different and in some cases special requirements of PaaS applications, and further recognize the importance of prioritizing those capabilities for delivery. It is only through this process that OpenStack, as a whole, will be able to deliver on its stated mission. Furthermore, the Technical Committee recommends that all PaaS application projects that need specific capabilities of the underlying Infrastructure Services identify these requirements and reference this resolution of the Technical Committee in their requests.

commit_message:
Fix some reST field lists in docstrings

Probably the most common format for documenting arguments is reST field
lists [1]. This change updates some docstrings to comply with the field
lists syntax.

[1] http://sphinx-doc.org/domains.html#info-field-lists

Change-Id: I36413c6f1e44dc586c98228d6abd9f38952f6391

deleted_lines: "POT-Creation-Date: 2017-03-17 03:18+0000\n"msgid "" "A week before Day 1: choice of a contribution, via email, with each " "participant" msgstr "" "Eine Woche vor Tag 1: Wähle einen Beitrag, per E-Mail, mit jedem Teilnehmer" msgid "Day 2: Individual presentation of the contribution plan" msgstr "Tag 2: Individuelle Präsentation des Beitragsplans" msgid "Day 2: Lego contribution simulation" msgstr "Tag 2: Lego Beitragssimmulation" msgid "Day 2: Online mentoring" msgstr "Tag 2: Online-Mentoring" msgid "Face-to-face section: 2 days" msgstr "Vor-Ort-Sektion: 2 Tage" msgid "" "Faster integration of the companies product roadmap into the OpenStack " "release cycle" msgstr "" "Schnellere Integration der Firmen-Produkt-Roadmap in den OpenStack Versions-" "Zyklus" msgid "" "Having at least 8 hours a week to dedicate to the project, be it through " "programming or through interacting with the community" msgstr "" "8 Stunden pro Woche Zeit haben für das Projekt, durch Programmierung oder " "Interaktion mit der Gemeinschaft." msgid "Ildiko Vancsa, Kendall Nelson, Mark Korondi, and Marton Kiss" msgstr "Ildiko Vancsa, Kendall Nelson, Mark Korondi und Marton Kiss" msgid "Master the technical tools" msgstr "Meistern Sie die technischen Werkzeuge" msgid "" "Online section: 10 one-hour individual mentoring sessions over a period of 4 " "to 10 weeks" msgstr "" "Online-Sektion: 10 x 1 Stunde individuelle Sitzung innerhalb von 4 bis 10 " "Wochen" msgid "OpenStack Upstream Training Details" msgstr "OpenStack Upstream Training Details" msgid "Prerequisites" msgstr "Vorbedingungen" msgid "Successfully contribute one real world patch to an OpenStack component" msgstr "Erfolgreicher Beitrag an echten Korrekturen von OpenStack Komponenten" "The trainers have led the training in Barcelona and will lead the next " "training in Boston, in English:" msgstr "" "Die Trainer haben das Training in Barcelona geleitet und werden das nächste " "Training in Boston leiten, in Englisch:" msgid """We've designed a training program to help professional developers negotiate " "this hurdle. It shows them how to ensure their bug fix or feature is " "accepted in the OpenStack project in a minimum amount of time. The " "educational program requires students to work on real-life bug fixes or new " "features during two days of real-life classes and online mentoring, until " "the work is accepted by OpenStack. The live two-day class teaches them to " "navigate the intricacies of the project's technical tools and social " "interactions. In a followup session, the students benefit from individual " "online sessions to help them resolve any remaining problems they might have." msgstr "" "Wir haben ein Trainingsprogamm entwickelt, um professionellen Entwicklern zu " "helfen, diese Hürde zu überwinden. Es wird gezeigt, wie Bug-Fixes und " "Feature-Anfragen mit einem minimalen Zeitaufwand ins Openstack-Projekt " "eingebracht werden können. Das Schulungsprogramm erfordert Arbeit an echten " "Bug-Fixes oder neuen Funktionen in 2 Tagen Klassenraum- oder " "Onlinesitzungen. Der 2-Tages-Kurs lehrt, in den technischen Werkzeugen und " "sozialen Interaktionen des Projekts zu navigieren. In einer Folgesitzung " "besteht die Möglichkeit, individuell auf Probleme und Fragen einzugehen." msgid ""msgid "When & Where to get OpenStack Upstream Training" msgstr "Wann und wo bekommt man das OpenStack Upstream Training" msgid "" "With over 2000 developers from 80 different companies worldwide, OpenStack " "is one of the largest collaborative software-development projects. Because " "of its size, it is characterized by a huge diversity in social norms and " "technical conventions. These can significantly slow down the speed at which " "newcomers are successful at integrating their own roadmap into that of the " "OpenStack project." msgstr "" "Mit mehr als 2000 Entwicklern aus 80 verschiedenen Unternehmen weltweit ist " "Openstack einer der größten kollaborativen Software-Entwicklungsprojekte. " "Aufgrund seiner Größe, wird es durch eine große Vielfalt in sozialen Normen " "und technischen Konventionen gekennzeichnet. Dies kann signifikat die " "Geschwindigkeit verlangsamen, mit der Neulinge ihren eigenen Fahrplan ins " "Openstack-Projekt integrieren." "`Etherpad for Barcelona Upstream Training <https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/" "upstream-training-barcelona>`_" msgstr "" "`Etherpad für das Barcelona Upstream Training <https://etherpad.openstack." "org/p/upstream-training-barcelona>`_" msgid ""msgid "" "`ready to use DevStack VM <https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/" "OpenStack_Upstream_Training/Setup_DevStack>`_ for participants with network " "connectivity but troubles with their laptop" msgstr "" "`bereit zur Benutzung der DevStack VM <https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/" "OpenStack_Upstream_Training/Setup_DevStack>`_ für Teilnehmer mit " "Netzwerkverbindung, aber Problemen mit ihrem Laptop"

commit_message:
Support Firewall as a service

Firewall is a necessary functionality in cloud infrastructure. This
spec decribes the design of firewal for Dragonflow

Co-Authored-By: hujie <mike.hu@huawei.com>

Partially-Implements: blueprint fwaas
Change-Id: I27746cb11a55132b72c704c586305daf6b32e9f9

to neutron/conf/agent/common.

subject: Add missing validation to consumer controller
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-03-22 00:46:20.000000000', 'files': ['barbican/common/validators.py', 'barbican/tests/api/controllers/test_consumers.py', 'functionaltests/api/v1/functional/test_consumers.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/barbican/commit/27cc58a5465c5e8b38a73a43eb2bc6ec67ca9593', 'message': 'Add missing validation to consumer controller

Name and URL are required data elements when creating a consumer.
Validation was done to ensure these fields were passed, but no
check was done to make sure these fields were not empty.

This patches adds a minLength validation and add corresponding

Change-Id: Ib33ab9b311c03ff7ba7f766e857496eb5b1602d4
Closes-bug: #1536748

commit_message:
Add missing validation to consumer controller

Name and URL are required data elements when creating a consumer.
Validation was done to ensure these fields were passed, but no
check was done to make sure these fields were not empty.

This patches adds a minLength validation and add corresponding
unit and functional test cases.

Change-Id: Ib33ab9b311c03ff7ba7f766e857496eb5b1602d4
Closes-bug: #1536748
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/barbican refs/changes/18/448318/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @testcase.attr('security') class ConsumersValidationTestCase(ConsumersBaseTestCase): def test_consumer_create_pass(self): """Create a valid consumer Should return 200 """ data = { "name": "consumername", "URL": "consumerURL" } model = consumer_model.ConsumerModel(**data) resp, consumer_dat = self.consumer_behaviors.create_consumer( model, self.generic_container_ref, use_auth=True ) self.assertEqual(200, resp.status_code) @testcase.attr('negative') def test_consumer_create_fail_no_name(self): """Attempt to create invalid consumer (Missing name) Should return 400 """ data = { "URL": "consumerURL" } model = consumer_model.ConsumerModel(**data) resp, consumer_dat = self.consumer_behaviors.create_consumer( model, self.generic_container_ref, use_auth=True ) self.assertEqual(400, resp.status_code) @testcase.attr('negative') def test_consumer_create_fail_no_url(self): """Attempt to create invalid consumer (Missing URL) Should return 400 """ data = { "name": "consumername" } model = consumer_model.ConsumerModel(**data) resp, consumer_dat = self.consumer_behaviors.create_consumer( model, self.generic_container_ref, use_auth=True ) self.assertEqual(400, resp.status_code) @testcase.attr('negative') def test_consumer_create_fail_empty_name(self): """Attempt to create invalid consumer (Empty name) Should return 400 """ data = { "name": "", "URL": "consumerURL" } model = consumer_model.ConsumerModel(**data) resp, consumer_dat = self.consumer_behaviors.create_consumer( model, self.generic_container_ref, use_auth=True ) self.assertEqual(400, resp.status_code) @testcase.attr('negative') def test_consumer_create_fail_empty_url(self): """Attempt to create invalid consumer (Empty URL) Should return 400 """ data = { "name": "consumername", "URL": "" } model = consumer_model.ConsumerModel(**data) resp, consumer_dat = self.consumer_behaviors.create_consumer( model, self.generic_container_ref, use_auth=True ) self.assertEqual(400, resp.status_code)

commit_message:
Handle vlan_id in dpdk/vxlan mode

On provision stage apply vlan_id from ovs bridge
to lnx port to pass connectivity check.

Change-Id: Id453f45773905f923c3d8e37650b21a0fb8be26b
Closes-Bug: #1673767
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/33/448133/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: :type => :rvalue, :arity => 1, :doc => <<-EOS raise( Puppet::ParseError, "remove_ovs_usage(): Wrong network_scheme. Should be non-empty Hash." ) unless argv[0].is_a?(Hash) raise( Puppet::ParseError, "remove_ovs_usage(): You network_scheme hash has wrong format.\nThis parser can work with v1.1 format, please convert you config." ) if argv[0]['version'].to_s.to_f < 1.1 transformations = argv[0]['transformations'] transformations.each do |tr| override_lnx = { # handle vxlan mode if tr['provider'] == 'dpdkovs' bridge = transformations.select { |t| tr['bridge'] == t['name'] } bridge_vlan_id = bridge[0]['vendor_specific']['vlan_id'] override_lnx.merge!({'name' => "#{tr['name']}.#{bridge_vlan_id}"}) if bridge_vlan_id end overrides << override_lnx unless overrides.empty?
deleted_lines: :type => :rvalue, :doc => <<-EOS def bridge_name_max_len 15 end if argv.size != 1 raise( Puppet::ParseError, "remove_ovs_usage(): Wrong number of arguments. Should be two." ) end if !argv[0].is_a?(Hash) raise( Puppet::ParseError, "remove_ovs_usage(): Wrong network_scheme. Should be non-empty Hash." ) end if argv[0]['version'].to_s.to_f < 1.1 raise( Puppet::ParseError, "remove_ovs_usage(): You network_scheme hash has wrong format.\nThis parser can work with v1.1 format, please convert you config." ) end network_scheme = argv[0] network_scheme['transformations'].each do |tr| overrides << { if ! overrides.empty?

subject: Remove log translations
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-03-21 04:44:55.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/dragonflow/commit/d73c0e585b08c7a62d49657483d74f06a1d663a4', 'message': 'Remove log translations

Log messages are no longer being translated. This removes all use of
the _LE, _LI, and _LW translation markers to simplify logging and to
avoid confusion with new contributions.

commit_message:
Remove log translations

Log messages are no longer being translated. This removes all use of
the _LE, _LI, and _LW translation markers to simplify logging and to
avoid confusion with new contributions.

See:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-i18n/2016-November/002574.html
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-March/113365.html

Change-Id: If51139eaa6f22165d052a6e6004ff52c93f536f3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/dragonflow refs/changes/94/447794/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: LOG.warning("RedisPortStatusNotifier cannot " "work when enable_df_pub_sub is disabled") LOG.warning("No neutron listener found")
deleted_lines: LOG.warning(_LW("RedisPortStatusNotifier cannot " "work when enable_df_pub_sub is disabled")) LOG.warning(_LW("No neutron listener found"))

commit_message:
Conform cgroups to systemd based services

Update cgroups configuration to be running on ubuntu 16.04.
Remove "cgroup-lite" package/service since systemd
mounts cgroups sanely itself.

Change-Id: I250f1ba92fbe1ceac415a73b640fd00d6e2898e4
Closes-Bug: #1669747
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/56/443556/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: $packages = ['cgroup-bin', 'libcgroup1']

subject: Add ability to translate net name to UUID
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-ironic refs/changes/44/449044/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: require 'puppet/provider/neutron' def to_net_uuid(name) neutron = Puppet::Provider::Neutron.new neutron.auth_neutron('net-show', "#{name}", '--format=value', '--column=id').chop end def from_net_uuid(uuid) neutron = Puppet::Provider::Neutron.new neutron.auth_neutron('net-show', "#{uuid}", '--format=value', '--column=name').chop end

subject: Sushy to adhere to the resource identifier portion of the spec
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-03-22 12:14:23.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/sushy/commit/10f60862d55e10e61bbe6ba0010278f63aad0a7a', 'message': 'Sushy to adhere to the resource identifier portion of the spec

This patch is intended to make the handle of the resources
identification more flexible in the library. Prior to this patch the
library had some assumptions about the path of a give resources and
tried to build such paths within it. Turns out that it's not that
simple, the Redfish specification does allow things like resources from
a different authority to be registered in a different controller [0].
I quote:

"Resources within the same authority as the request URI shall be
represented according to the rules of path-absolute defined by that
specification. That is, they shall always start with a single forward
slash ("/"). Resources within a different authority as the request URI
shall start with a double-slash ("//") followed by the authority and
path to the resource."

That means that, members of a collection could
be either: "/redfish/v1/Systems/12345" or
"//another-service.com/redfish/v1/Systems/12345"

This break many of the assumptions we had before of how to handle these
resources from the controller.

So, this patch is basically making sushy more "dumb" about the location
of the resources by not trying to build the URI for it but instead just
relying on the URI returned from the members of a collection or other
attributes of a specific resource. One example here was the "target"
attribute of the #ComputerSystem.Reset reset action, prior to this patch
we needed to strip portions of the URI (the /redfish/v1) in order to fit
the model that we use to construct the URLs now, that's not needed
anymore.

Note that, this patch is non-backward compatible and changes the usage
of the library but, since we haven't had any release yet (so it's not
even alpha or beta, but completely under-development) it seems to be the
right time for such a change.

[0] http://redfish.dmtf.org/schemas/DSP0266_1.1.html#resource-identifier-property

Change-Id: Ia4211ebb3b99f6cc4bd695b5dbea2018d301de33
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2017-03-22 12:16:18.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/sushy/commit/863e389269edde97ac9ef0776dd24d9596ad31ea', 'message': 'Sushy to adhere to the resource identifier portion of the spec

a different authority to be registered in a different controller [0].
I quote:

"Resources within the same authority as the request URI shall be
represented according to the rules of path-absolute defined by that
specification. That is, they shall always start with a single forward
slash ("/"). Resources within a different authority as the request URI
shall start with a double-slash ("//") followed by the authority and
path to the resource."

That means that, members of a collection could
be either: "/redfish/v1/Systems/12345" or
"//another-service.com/redfish/v1/Systems/12345"

This breaks many of the assumptions we had before of how to handle these
resources from the controller.

So, this patch is basically making sushy more "dumb" about the location
of the resources by not trying to build the URI for it but instead just
relying on the URI returned from the members of a collection or other
attributes of a specific resource. One example here was the "target"
attribute of the #ComputerSystem.Reset reset action, prior to this patch
we needed to strip portions of the URI (the /redfish/v1) in order to fit
the model that we use to construct the URLs now, that's not needed
anymore.

Note that, this patch is non-backward compatible and changes the usage
of the library but, since we haven't had any release yet (so it's not
even alpha or beta, but completely under-development) it seems to be the
right time for such a change.

[0] http://redfish.dmtf.org/schemas/DSP0266_1.1.html#resource-identifier-property

Change-Id: Ia4211ebb3b99f6cc4bd695b5dbea2018d301de33

commit_message:
Sushy to adhere to the resource identifier portion of the spec

This patch is intended to make the handle of the resources
identification more flexible in the library. Prior to this patch the
library had some assumptions about the path of a given resource and
tried to build such paths within it. Turns out that it's not that
simple, the Redfish specification does allow things like resources from
a different authority to be registered in a different controller [0].
I quote:

"Resources within the same authority as the request URI shall be
represented according to the rules of path-absolute defined by that
specification. That is, they shall always start with a single forward
slash ("/"). Resources within a different authority as the request URI
shall start with a double-slash ("//") followed by the authority and
path to the resource."

That means that, members of a collection could
be either: "/redfish/v1/Systems/12345" or
"//another-service.com/redfish/v1/Systems/12345"

This breaks many of the assumptions we had before of how to handle these
resources from the controller.

So, this patch is basically making sushy more "dumb" about the location
of the resources by not trying to build the URI for it but instead just
relying on the URI returned from the members of a collection or other
attributes of a specific resource. One example here was the "target"
attribute of the #ComputerSystem.Reset reset action, prior to this patch
we needed to strip portions of the URI (the /redfish/v1) in order to fit
the model that we use to construct the URLs now, that's not needed
anymore.

Note that, this patch is non-backward compatible and changes the usage
of the library but, since we haven't had any release yet (so it's not
even alpha or beta, but completely under-development) it seems to be the
right time for such a change.

[0] http://redfish.dmtf.org/schemas/DSP0266_1.1.html#resource-identifier-property

Change-Id: Ia4211ebb3b99f6cc4bd695b5dbea2018d301de33

commit_message:
Switch to use test_utils.call_until_true

test.call_until_true has been deprecated since Newton on Tempest side,
and now Tempest provides test_utils.call_until_true as the stable
library method. So this patch switches to use the stable method before
removing old test.call_until_true on Tempest side.

Change-Id: I5e82466f6eb7b164042406813b1ad72a1cbb05fa

commit_message:
Add skip method for volume test with the glance service

In some tests, it try to create volume with image
 "VolumesV2ImageMetadata",
 "test_create_from_bootable_volume",
 "test_bootable_volume_backup_and_restore",
so it should be check Glance is available before test.
If all tests in class is associate with glance, I used skip_checks,
and otherwise, I used testtools.SkipIf

Change-Id: Ic200b5ce33cf57a78554b0f3611ec5f90473a864
Closes-Bug: 1675700

added_lines: def skip_checks(cls): super(VolumesV2ImageMetadata, cls).skip_checks() if not CONF.service_available.glance: skip_msg = ("%s skipped as Glance is not available" % cls.__name__) raise cls.skipException(skip_msg) @classmethod

commit_message:
Fixing headers and user metadata in copy

This patch fixes a bug that was introduced in the latest
'run copy on object node' change as well as previous bug:

1. One bug was that we called _set_metadata_in_headers
   twice: One from the PUT flow and then again from
   handle_put_copy_response
2. The other bug was calling _set_metadata_in_headers
   in the case of a copy where the execution is not
   done in the proxy, and the object node already
   takes care of the user metadata.
3. We have neglected to copy the get request headers
   coming from the object node before calling the put

Change-Id: I7ea2a9f011a3050f44ee9bf7e117e758ff24c5de

commit_message:
Port Chain Tap for passive Service Function

Change-Id: I653bd8ae0e23ddc2c16be4ba372f7bd63312f7d5
Co-Authored-By: Cathy Zhang <cathy.h.zhang@huawei.com>
Co-Authored-By: Farhad Sunavala <farhad.sunavala@huawei.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-sfc refs/changes/95/442195/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ==================================== Service Function Tap for Port Chains ==================================== Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/networking-sfc/+spec/sfc-tap-port-pair This specification describes the support for passive Service Functions in SFC Port Chains. Problem Description =================== There are some Service Functions (SF) that operate in a passive mode and only receive packets on the ingress port but do not send packets on an egress port. An example of this is a Service Function that has an Intrusion Detection Service (IDS). In order to include such a SF in a port chain, the packets must be delivered to this SF and also forwarded on to the next downstream SF in the port chain. Proposed Changes ================ The Port Pair service-function-parameter attribute allows service specific configuration to be applied to a Service Function. The service-function-parameter will be enhanced to add an "insertion-mode" field. This field is set to "passive" to indicate that the data-plane switch behavior will be to send the packets to the ingress port of the SF and also forward these packets to the next hop SF. This port-pair will in effect operate as a tap by passing packets to the passive SF and also forwarding these packets to the next downstream SF. This port-pair will not receive any packets from a SF. If this parameter is set to none or is not present then normal behavior will occur. OVS Bridge Implementation ------------------------- If the insertion-mode for a SF is configured as "passive" the OVS Integration bridge will add a tap. The tap replicates packets received from upstream SFs. One copy is sent to the ingress port (P1) of SF 1 on VM1. The other copy is sent to the ingress port P2 of SF 2 on VM2. :: Compute Node +--------------------------------------------------+ | VM1 VM2 | | +--------------------+ +--------------------+ | | | Service Function 1 | | Service Function 2 | | | | (Passive) | | | | | +--------------------+ +--------------------+ | | P1 |^ P2 |^ P3 |. | | |. |. |. | | |. |. |. | | +----------.-------------------.--------.----+ | | | . . . | | | | Tap x.........>.......... . | | | | . . | | | | ...>..... OVS Integration ...> | | | | Bridge | | | | | | | +--------------------------------------------+ | | | +--------------------------------------------------+ Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- Add "insertion-mode" to the service-function-parameter. REST API impact --------------- Add "insertion-mode": "passive" to the service-function-parameter. Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None. Developer impact ---------------- None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- * Cathy Zhang (cathy.h.zhang@huawei.com) * Louis Fourie (louis.fourie@huawei.com) * Farhad Sunavala (farhad.sunavala@huawei.com) Work Items ---------- 1. Extend API service-function-parameter to support "insertion-mode" attribute. 2. Extend 'networking-sfc' OVS driver to support "insertion-mode" attribute. 3. Add unit and functional tests. 4. Update documentation. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Unit tests and functional tests will be added. Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== None

commit_message:
Alternative for warning users about maintenance

Some thoughts in spec form.

Please DO NOT MERGE this half baked nonsense.

Change-Id: I2a4f785193236b9d238fcd36eab6167c0a0f8b0a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/93/449593/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Help applications running on top of OpenStack avoid the impact of any planned host maintenance.Due to the sensitive nature of these workloads, live-migration is not good enough to avoiding the impact of any planned maintenance. You want those users to build new workers that will land on hosts that will be impacted at a different time to their affected instance. Operator wise, you want to limit the impact of the maintenance on all users. As such, you want to: * Warn users (and automated systems via a notification) when an instance is about to be impacted by some maintenance on the host the instance is currently on. * Don't build any new instances on hosts about to be impacted by maintenance. Some operators may want to allow that if there is no capacity on hosts that are either already patches or not yet impacted. * Operators now needs to wait for "maintenance aware" applications to either delete or shutdown instances on affected hosts. There should be a clear SLA on how long the operator will wait (user needs to know the expected start time of the maintenance) They may spin up new instances, making use of the above system to ensure they land on a host that will not be impacted by the same pending maintenance. * As soon as the host is being emptied, just before the maintenance starts, strictly no new builds or moves should be allowed onto that host. * After the maintenance is complete, no user workloads are allowed on that host, except for the test builds the operator lands on that specific host. Once tests are complete, the server is open to receive new workloads (either from user builds, or migrations from the next set of impacted hosts) Nova currently supports some of this flow: * Majority of cloud native applications can deal with the downtime that occurs when you reboot a server. The majority of non-cloud aware can deal with being live-migrated to avoid any downtime. But there are still workloads that need to take pro-active steps to avoid downtime when there is planned maintenance. Today this can be done via a third party "signaling" system, such as email, or a separate notification or API system, such as adding tags or metadata on a users affected instances. But this hurts the interoperability of applications written for OpenStack. * You can disable a host you are about to empty using live-migration. This will stop new user builds landing on the host, while still allowing the move operations to be executed. * Operators can still force a build to land on a disabled host (TODO - did we fix the bug around that having got broken). This means a host can stay disabled for the duration of the maintenance and the tests done post maintenance to ensure the host is working. So the key problem we need to address in this spec is having a way to warn users of pending maintenance that is interoperable. Not covered in this spec is a away to prefer building to hosts that are not about to be impacted. Operators are still able to disable a host to ensure no new builds land on a host that is about to be impacted, but that may cause too much pressure on the cloud's capacity.TODO - see above.Firstly, the operator should continue to disable any affected service. This should only be done when you are happy for no new builds to land on that host. You should only enable a service after you have validated the maintenance was successful, and you are happy for new builds to land on the host. In the service table we add this information: * ``maintenance_url`` as string of max length 255 * ``maintenance_expected_start_time`` as datetime This is set by adding a new API (note depended on uuid being added):: PUT /v2.1/os-services/{uuid}/maintenance-info { "maintenance_info": { "url": "https://my-maintenance-app/uuid-123", "expected_start_time": "..." } } You can clear the maintenance info doing this:: PUT /v2.1/os-services/{uuid}/maintenance-info { "maintenance_info": {} } Changing the above information should trigger a ``service.update`` notification. Updated version of the notification should include the new fields. (TODO - what about also sending "instance.save" notifications?) GET /v2.1/os-services { "services": [ { "id": "uuid-321", "binary": "nova-compute", "disabled_reason": "test1", "host": "host1", "state": "up", "status": "disabled", "updated_at": "2012-10-29T13:42:02.000000", "forced_down": false, "zone": "internal", "maintenance_info": { "url": "https://my-maintenance-app/uuid-123", "expected_start_time": "..." } }, ... } Now we know about also needs to notify any affected instances. We do this by adding the above new field into the detailed response of a server, specifically:: GET /v2.1/servers/{server_id} GET /v2.1/servers/detail By default this URL will be visible to all users, there is no separate policy. It will look like this:: { "server": { "uuid": "...", ..., "maintenance_info": { "url": "https://my-maintenance-app/uuid-123", "expected_start_time": "..." } } Note there is no policy to control the visibility of this tag, it is available to all users that can view the server information. If an operator does not want to expose this information, they should not set this information on the appropriate services.We could look at having a top level maintenance construct, so you set what services are affected by a particular maintenance event. We could add a uuid to link the individual services that are updated. But for now, we can make the poor assumption that if its the same maintenance event it will have the same URL. Service ``disable_reason`` could be extended to deal with things before and after the event. But this proposes we use disable to signal the stopping of builds on the service, and maintenance-info is to warn about a pending event and as such is independent.TODO...TODOTODO...
deleted_lines: User needs to obtain more detailed information about compute host maintenance which is affecting his servers.In NFV there is automated actions in host failure to migrate VMs and there is RCA engine like Vitrage to have alarms about problems on host. In planned host maintenance one needs to have an alarm about coming maintenance and to differentiate from failure case. You do not want some host monitoring to incorrectly indicate about host problem because of planned maintenance. In planned maintenance you need to have time to prepare and make sure application running on the host has finished all subscriber actions (NFV mobile network case) and running safely on a host not impacted by maintenance. Also you can make even more sophisticated decisions, like not to migrate your VMs anywhere as the downtime of a host will be short. Surely you also need to know your VM state regarding planned maintenance trough an API. Delicate NFV upgrade/maintenance goes rolling node by node kind of fashion. It has to make sure instance of certain application service is always running on a host not affected by upgrade/maintenance or is already gone trough the process. Also for some type of instances you have to guarantee certain amount of instances continuously running to not to degrade service. This means you would simply need to run operation one host at a time or more intelligently couple of hosts at a time. Operator wants a simple way of testing maintained host by making this possible by scheduling instead of the need of using availability zones. At the same time forbidding scheduling from other users. Normal user would want to be allowed to schedule to a host in planned maintenance in case it is not possible on a host not impacted by maintenance. Scheduling needs to be possible only to hosts that have gone trough maintenance.* As a user I want to know when planned host maintenance is going to happen: User can have application that needs zero downtime guaranteed over planned maintenance operation. Planned maintenance need to be known before it happens, so NFV application can have time to finish ongoing subscriber operations and start to serve them on a VM on a host not affected by maintenance. During maintenance VMs can then safely be migrated without effect to service application is offering. Maintenance state should be possible to see by querying VMs and by notifications/alarms. NFV use case is that there is external service for monitoring hosts and triggering alarms. It should know about planned host maintenance via a notification so it can alarm the user having VMs running on the host. There needs to be external workflow that automatically do needed actions to migrate VMs. It needs to be possible to know which VMs will be under maintenance at what time, so application can make sure to deliver continuous service. * As an admin I want to have an external tool to handle hosts and their maintenance: Admin wants to have a tool where he can manage all hosts in his cloud. This kind of a tool can have a planned maintenance state and other deeper information about different hosts and an ability to run different workflows accordingly. Changes to maintenance states can be consumed by other services trough notifications or be available via a tool CLI and REST API. External workflow engine can also be used as there should be notifications about changing host maintenance state. Typical maintenance workflow could: disable compute, live migrate VMs, disable monitoring, patch the host, reboot host, post patch host, enable monitoring and enable compute. As tool knows planned maintenance it also need to update necessary information about maintenance event to Nova. Information is needed by the owners of VMs as well as for defining different scheduling scenarios. Planned maintenance needs to be able to be set in rolling manner for set of hosts or single host at a time. This is to help application to minimize the impact on service, guarantee no degradation of service and to have enough hosts available to migrate VMs. * As an admin I want monitoring/alarming/RCA system to adapt to host maintenance state: RCA engine like Vitrage need to know when host is in maintenance. It needs to receive a notification when planned maintenance state of a host changes. It can then ignore certain monitoring events that would normally raise failure alarms and cause automatic actions accordingly. Instead there should be alarms about planned maintenance state changes, so that user running VMs on host would know that. * As a user I may want to schedule to a host going into planned maintenance soon or prevent it: Maintenance state with start and stop time could enable making of scheduling filter that could optionally disable scheduling to a host that will be going to maintenance soon or have a weight to schedule there only if no other host available. Both scenarios can come handy. During maintenance you will have less resource capacity so you may still want to take everything out of existing capacity if some hosts are anyhow not entering to maintenance for a while. On the other hand you may only want to schedule to host that has gone trough maintenance, or prevent several migrations of a VM by not allowing scheduling to host that is planned to go maintenance soon. * As a user I may want only to schedule to a already maintained host: Maintenance state telling about planned or ongoing maintenance on host enables the possibility to only schedule to maintained host. * As an admin I want to schedule server to a host in ongoing maintenance to test everything works after maintenance. Same time I want to prevent other users to schedule server to host. Planned maintenance state can enable making of scheduling filter that can prevent normal user from scheduling to a host that is under maintenance, but allow it to admin needing to test host works after maintenance. This would easy up admin work of currently doing the same with availability zones. Enable/disable nova-compute would only be used when nobody is allowed to schedule to host.It is seen that planned host maintenance should be built to an external tool that have detailed host information and maintenance workflow. At the same, it still remains to find the minimum integration to Nova to fulfill all the requirements. Currently there is work ongoing to implement this to inventory and fleet management project Craton. While this resides outside Nova, the maintenance event need to be known in the Nova content to enable all the above use cases. New field should be added to services table in Nova DB: * ``host_description`` as string This could be set by adding a new API:: PUT /v2.1/{tenant_id}/os-services/host-description Changing the ``host_description`` should trigger a ``service.update`` notification. Updated version of the notification should include the new field. Craton will also be sending notification, but for generic usage of new field, notification should also be sent from Nova. External tool like Vitrage could catch this and send alarms so users to know which of their server instances are affected and enable/disable monitoring of the host. While notification will have an ability to expose information, it needs to be possible to see it also in the Nova APIs. The new field should also be visible as parameters in response of APIs:: GET /v2.1/{tenant_id}/servers/{server_id} GET /v2.1/{tenant_id}/servers/detail A new policy is needed to have this visible in the above APIs:: "os_compute_api:servers:show:host_maintenance": "rule:admin_or_owner" GET /v2.1/{tenant_id}/os-servicesService ``disable_reason`` could be used by changing how it can be set and by exposing it to servers API. Anyhow this would widen the scope of its usage and it would not be descriptive name for different usage possibilities. New field could alternatively be an unique id that links to an external tool. Planned maintenance is anyhow seen something that should be seen directly and not on every call to be checked somewhere else. Unique id might also make usage of the new field tightly coupled to specific external tool.New column should be added to the ``services`` table in Nova DB by migration script:: Column('host_description', String(255), nullable=True)A single new microversion is needed for the new API to set host description and to show it in relevant existing API responses. API for setting host maintenance:: PUT /v2.1/{tenant_id}/os-services/host-description { "host": "host1", "binary": "nova-compute", "host_description": "{\"maintenance_state\":\"MAINTENANCE\", \"maintenance_reason\": \"reason for host maintenance\", \"maintenance_start\": \"2017-03-22T00:46:25Z\", \"maintenance_end\": \"2017-03-22T01:46:25Z\"}" } 200 OK { "service": { "host": "host1", "binary": "nova-compute", "host_description": "{\"maintenance_state\":\"MAINTENANCE\", \"maintenance_reason\": \"reason for host maintenance\", \"maintenance_start\": \"2017-03-22T00:46:25Z\", \"maintenance_end\": \"2017-03-22T01:46:25Z\"}" } } Servers APIs that will have new field shown in response message:: GET /v2.1/{tenant_id}/servers/{server_id} GET /v2.1/{tenant_id}/servers/detail Example of showing new parameter in the above APIs response:: GET /v2.1/{tenant_id}/servers/{server_id} 200 OK { "server": { ... "host_description": "{\"maintenance_state\":\"MAINTENANCE\", \"maintenance_reason\": \"reason for host maintenance\", \"maintenance_start\": \"2017-03-22T00:46:25Z\", \"maintenance_end\": \"2017-03-22T01:46:25Z\"}", ... } } Example of showing new parameter in ``GET /v2.1/{tenant_id}/os-services`` response:: GET /v2.1/{tenant_id}/os-services 200 OK { "services": [ ... { "id": 2, "binary": "nova-compute", "disabled_reason": "Maintenance", "host": "host1", "state": "up", "status": "disabled", "updated_at": "2017-03-22T00:46:25.211575", "forced_down": false, "zone": "nova", "host_description": "{\"maintenance_state\":\"MAINTENANCE\", \"maintenance_reason\": \"reason for host maintenance\", \"maintenance_start\": \"2017-03-22T00:46:25Z\", \"maintenance_end\": \"2017-03-22T01:46:25Z\"}", }, ... ] } Novaclient will need support for setting host description. Response for APIs just showing the new field should be straightforward, but for setting host maintenance there needs to be a new CLI command:: $ nova service-host-description <hostname> <binary> <description> +------------------+-----------------------------------------------------+ | Property | Value | +------------------+-----------------------------------------------------+ | Host | host1 | +------------------+-----------------------------------------------------+ | Binary | nova-compute | +------------------+-----------------------------------------------------+ | host_description | {"maintenance_state": "MAINTENANCE", "maintenance_r | | | eason": "reason for host maintenance", "maintenance | | | _start": "2017-03-22T00:46:25Z", "maintenance_end": | | | "2017-03-22T01:46:25Z"} | +------------------+-----------------------------------------------------+

commit_message:
Batches roles ResourceGroup creation and update

Supports a new parameter in roles_data.yaml called create_batch_size
to configure the batching size to use when creating instances the
roles ResourceGroup. Defaults to 30.

Change-Id: I3901f641f8e4c2d5eb6e9aa49547979d88efe50a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/39/439039/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # create_batch_size: (number): batch size for role creation. # This defaults to 32, but larger or smaller batches may be specified here. #

commit_message:
Update test-requirements.txt

This patch brings it in line with the latest global requirements.
By being in line with global requirements, this is a more accurate
list with respect to how things are actually tested in the gate.
The following links[0][1][2] show the latest reno, oslosphinx, sphinx
packages.

[0]https://github.com/openstack/requirements/blob/master/global-requirements.txt#L263
[1]https://github.com/openstack/requirements/blob/master/global-requirements.txt#L372
[2]https://github.com/openstack/requirements/blob/master/global-requirements.txt#L395

Change-Id: I70e863a6abfc5bb4b8f73682bcf87bf5e303c147

commit_message:
Fix a doc problem in receiver message sample

This patch fixes the recevier doc problem which will make message action
can't be created succeeded.

Change-Id: Ida0548fc46c6d2423f8d266b89854f63bc0a1b99
Closes-Bug: #1675726

For the function "validate" in senlin/policies/scaling_policy.py,

commit_message:
There is no need to check if the input is None or not.

Found on Master branch.

For the function "validate" in senlin/policies/scaling_policy.py,
the check to make sure self.adjustment_min_step,
self.cooldown and self.adjustment_number is validate is not needed.

The validattion for their type is already constrained by schema type.

Change-Id: I3c7fa5978ff768540abf70d25cfee6bad5da736f
Closes-Bug: #1675630
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/senlin refs/changes/30/449430/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if self.adjustment_number <= 0: if self.adjustment_min_step < 0: if self.cooldown < 0:
deleted_lines: if self.adjustment_number is not None and self.adjustment_number <= 0: if (self.adjustment_min_step is not None and self.adjustment_min_step < 0): if self.cooldown is not None and self.cooldown < 0:
